newsitem.title: LIBYA: U.N., medical officials visit Libya-Egypt camp.
newsitem.headline: U.N., medical officials visit Libya-Egypt camp.

text.p: U.N. and aid officials visited a Libyan-Egyptian border camp on Saturday to find out what happened when Libyan policemen and soldiers forced more than 200 Palestinian refugees there to suddenly return to Libya.
One aid official told Reuters by telephone it was not clear where the refugees were taken.
"The Libyans arrived at 4 a.m. on Friday. It is not clear whether they were taken to Tubruq or Benghzai," said Eric Stobbaerts of Medecins sans Frontieres (MSF), who visited the site.
He said officials from the United Nations High Commission for Refugees were also at the camp near Salloum on the Mediterranean coast.
"It seems clear that international attention pressured the Libyans to find a solution to the problem, and one solution was to return them to Libya."
Stobbaerts said MSF was concerned about refugees who needed medical care for heart conditions or diabetes.

Bulldozers have started knocking down the tents and crude shops the refugees had set up to try to make a living and people's belongings strewn about the camp made it appear the site was abandoned in haste, travellers said.
Travellers had said on Friday that they saw the armed police and soldiers beat the refugees to make them board the buses.
The refugees had been living at the camp since September 1995, where Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi expelled them to punish the Palestinian leadership for making peace with Israel.

Libya reversed its policy on the refugees in January, saying it was not possible for them to go home to Palestinian-ruled areas. The Palestinians refused to return, saying they would rather go to Egypt or instead to self-rule areas.
Israel has entry rights to the Palestinian areas under peace deals.
Egypt would not let them in unless they could prove a third country would give them residence. It has made some exceptions in cases of emergency health problems.
